content: How can I help you today?
I've been struggling to sleep lately. There's just so much on my mind, mostly about work and finances. My partner encouraged me to come here, but honestly, I'm not sure if this will help.

Thank you for sharing that. It sounds like there's a lot weighing on you right now, and sleep has been hard to come by. It's understandable that work and finances can be a big source of stress. What has sleep been like for you recently?

It’s been bad. I keep tossing and turning, and I can’t stop thinking about work—like, what if I get fired? And then, to distract myself, I end up scrolling on my phone, which I know doesn’t help, but it’s hard to stop.

That sounds exhausting—lying there with thoughts circling and then turning to your phone for some relief, even knowing it might make sleep harder. It seems like there's a lot of worry tied to your work situation. Have you noticed if there’s anything specific that triggers those thoughts or makes it especially tough to unwind?

It’s mostly at night when everything’s quiet. My mind just won’t stop thinking about all the things that could go wrong—like losing my job, not being able to pay the bills, and how that would affect my family. It’s like I can’t shut it off.

The quiet at night can really amplify those concerns, especially when they're about things as important as job stability and taking care of your family. It sounds like your responsibilities and worries are deeply connected to how much you care about your loved ones. Have you found anything that helps, even a little, to quiet your mind or manage these thoughts?

Not really. Sometimes I think talking to my partner helps, but I don’t want to burden them too much with all my worries. And, honestly, other than scrolling my phone, I haven’t tried much else to deal with it. I just feel stuck.

It can feel isolating when you’re trying to carry the weight on your own, even though talking to your partner has offered some relief. It shows how much you value their well-being, even as you’re trying to navigate your own challenges. Feeling stuck can be tough—what would make trying something new feel easier or more possible for you right now?

It’s hard to say. I guess I don’t even know where to start or what would actually help. Part of me feels like it won’t make a difference, so I just keep doing the same thing. But I do want to feel less stuck—I just don’t know how.

Not knowing where to start and feeling uncertain about whether change will help can make it harder to take that first step, especially when it feels like the same routines provide some comfort, even if they don’t fully solve the problem. It’s powerful that you’ve shared you want to feel less stuck, though—and it sounds like you’re open to exploring what could make a difference. What would a better night’s sleep or less worry mean for you?

I think being able to sleep better would help me feel less tired and less irritable during the day—it might even help me focus more at work. And if I wasn’t so worried all the time, I feel like I’d be a better parent and more present with my kids. I just want to feel like I’m handling things instead of constantly feeling overwhelmed.

It sounds like better sleep and less worry would mean not only feeling more energized and focused but also being able to show up fully for your kids and enjoy those moments with them. That hope for a change—being more present and feeling capable of handling life’s challenges—is really meaningful. What do you think could help set you on a path toward feeling more in control?

I’m not totally sure, honestly. Maybe finding a way to relax or stop the racing thoughts at night would help, but I have no idea how to even do that. It feels like my mind just doesn’t have an off switch.

It sounds frustrating to feel like your mind keeps racing and doesn’t have an off switch—especially when you're genuinely looking for a way to find calm. Exploring ways to relax or ease those thoughts might be a helpful starting point. Would it feel okay to talk about ideas together or explore what relaxation might look like for you?
I’m open to hearing some ideas. I’m not sure what will work, but I guess it’s worth a try if it might help.

That openness is a great step, even when it’s hard to imagine what might help. Before diving into ideas, is there anything else you'd like to share about what’s been going on or what’s feeling most important to you right now?

I guess what feels most important is finding a way to not feel so overwhelmed all the time—for myself and for my family. I want to be able to handle things better and not let this stress control everything.

Thank you for sharing that—it’s clear how deeply you care about being a steady presence for yourself and your family. You’re looking for a way to feel more grounded and regain some control over the stress that’s been overwhelming you. Would you like to explore small, manageable steps together that could work toward that goal?
Yes, I think that could help. I’m open to trying small steps if they might make a difference. What kind of things should I try?

Before offering any ideas, here's a quick summary: you've been feeling stressed about work and finances, which has been affecting your sleep and overall wellbeing. You’re looking for ways to ease the overwhelm, improve sleep, and be more present and grounded, especially for your family. You’ve shared that you’re open to trying small steps. Would it feel okay to discuss some possibilities that could help with relaxation or calming your thoughts at night?
